title: All-Purpose Pie Crust (Pâte Brisée)
description:
This has become my go-to, workhorse, flaky, buttery pie crust that works well with everything I've thrown in it.

 Thanks to [ChefSteps](https://www.chefsteps.com/activities/buttery-flaky-all-purpose-pie-crust-pate-brisee) for this recipe.

directions.title: Make the dough
steps: Combine flour, butter, and salt in the bowl of a stand mixer.

Place the bowl of ingredients and the paddle attachment in the refrigerator until cold.
You want to keep all ingredients as cool as possible throughout the process.
Using the paddle attachment, mix on low until you get coarse crumbs.
Add water and mix just until dough comes together smoothly, about 1 minute.
Remove dough from mixing bowl and form into smooth ball. Flour hands and board as needed.
Press ball into a disk about 4cm thick.

Wrap with plastic and refrigerate for at least four hours.
This keeps the dough from shrinking, warping, and pulling away from the pan when you bake it.

directions.title: Roll and rest

image.title: Raw pie crust
image.alt: Raw pie crust in the pie plate

steps: Remove dough from the fridge and roll out on floured surface until it is about an inch wider than your desired baking dish.
Mold dough into desired shape in baking dish. Fold edges under the sides of the dish and trim excess.

Using a fork or dough docker, poke holes in the bottom of your crust.
This prevents large pockets of dough from puffing up under your filling or during the blind bake.

Refrigerate, uncovered, for at least one hour. Overnight is best.
If you do this, cover in plastic wrap after one hour, once the dough has hardened.

directions.title: Fill and bake
steps: If making pecan or apple or other less liquidy pies, add filling to dough and bake as needed.
For quiche, pumpkin pie, and other liquidy fillings, follow blind baking instructions.

directions.title: Blind bake
steps: Cut a piece of parchment paper with extra room to fit into your baking dish.
Crumple the paper into a ball and then flatten it back out. This makes fitting it down into your dish easier
Place weights on top of the parchment paper. (Rice, Dry Beans, or dedicated pie weights will work)
Remove weights. Bake another five minutes, or until nicely browned and flaky.
